elements.text: Thanks for this Sean. I've included you in this quick post:

text:
So, I've been actively interviewing for a few roles. I've been asked in the past to do writing tests (I understand that) but I'm concerned about companies possibly getting candidates to do work for free. I'm in interviews with a company to be their Content Manager. I'm looking to see if their "writing test / assignment" is too much?... Here's their ask:

For the next step, we would like you to complete a small project for us. We’d like you to take your best shot at creating a content marketing plan with short and long term strategy (3-12 months) in mind. 
Our target is 4x ARR growth YoY. How would your content strategy help us achieve that?

What would be the structure and deliverables:
• Types of content
• Calendar
• KPIs
• Team
Task #2: A sample blog post (600-800 words) that you feel would convert a visitor currently managing a mobile app translation project via spreadsheets to sign up for a free trial of our product.
You can focus the article on one of the following topics or freely choose your own:
1. Localization workflow management
2. Translation quality and consistency
3. International expansion ROI 
The deadline is next Thursday (20th August), but please inform me if the deadline does not work for you, and we will agree on other term

text:
Wait, isn't the job to set the content strategy short term and long term? That's crazy.

Also, a flexible deadline is not a deadline really is it?

Is it a respectable company you've heard of / worked with / can ask someone about?

text:
If their idea of a "plan" is actually answering these, I'd say it was fine:

Our target is 4x ARR growth YoY. How would your content strategy help us achieve that?

What would be the structure and deliverables:
• Types of content
• Calendar
• KPIs
• Team
But it reads like they want you to do a month's work by Thursday.

text:
<@U017WA1NKT4> Just one more person here to say this seems like too much (and good luck on your job search)! And while there are always sketchy folks out there looking for free work, to play devil’s advocate, I wonder how in-depth they want you to go?

The reason I ask is that I’ve used similar, but scaled well down, exercise for candidates in the past (e.g. create a one-page campaign plan with goals and a six-week timeline, write a 300-400 word blog post). We usually ask candidates to spend no more than two hours on the exercise but to tell us what they would’ve wanted to do with more time.

It seems ridiculous to ask someone for an entire short- and long-term marketing plan so I’m wondering what the actual expectation is in terms of scope and level of detail, or if they just want to see how you think/how you would structure it but aren’t expecting something very fleshed out.

elements.text:

We usually ask candidates to spend no more than two hours on the exercise but to tell us what they would’ve wanted to do with more time.

It seems ridiculous to ask someone for an entire short- and long-term marketing plan so I’m wondering what the actual expectation is in terms of scope and level of detail, or if they just want to see how you think/how you would structure it but aren’t expecting something very fleshed out.

text: This is nuts. IF someone asked for this I’d offer a high level walk through presentation of how i go through my strategy and a short sample of a blog (like title, intro, then an outline of how it would go and how CTAs would work.) But that’s it. Also if it’s not a more junior role a  writing test is kinda off..I save very small writing assignments for entry level positions because at that point most people have only had their work heavily edited…I’d be cautious and give feeedback and see how they react. if it isn’t well….you may have your answer :disappointed:

text: I am typically ok with a writing test… as a nerdy introvert, being able to show people - no really, don’t worry, I’m a good writer - can make up for my lack of charm in an interview :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing: BUT when it comes to making a strategy, I draw a hard line. Describing HOW I’d do it is one thing, but actually doing that kind of work for free, nah. I argued against this when we were hiring a director - it was a role that was too senior to ask for spec work like that IMO.

elements.text: I am typically ok with a writing test… as a nerdy introvert, being able to show people - no really, don’t worry, I’m a good writer - can make up for my lack of charm in an interview

text: That strategy is almost certainly a project that needs to be done over an extended period of time. Unique writing samples in that range is one thing, but to ask someone for a complete strategy is absurd. I wouldn't even offer to provide either and ask what they'd pay you for that work first. Because that is basically a freelance contract's worth of work just to apply.

text:
I co-hosted a LinkedIn Live stream from March to Mid-July, every week, often multiple times per week. It was pretty successful by most measures but it took a lot of work to get there and it was something our audience was really craving.
• We would get about 30-60 people live and then many views (1000s) after the fact. 
• We paired the live stream with reminder emails, show summaries, and downloads from the experts featured on the show. 
• We took the recorded streams and chopped them up into bite size snippets for social promotion, that we circulated on social and to our experts/influencers that made them want to share. 
• We targetted guests who were charasmatic and had big followings, hoping they would drive viewers, which was relatively rare
• We would have the same 10-20 people on every stream, and people were genuinely upset when we decided to take a break
• Our sales team said that it really helped with prospecting because people had actually already seen the show or heard of it, and if they hadn’t and they suggested it they said it made our brand look really high-quality and cool
• We actively encouraged people to chat and ask questions which was great for engagement
• We heavily branded and structured the show, which people really responded to
• We transcribed all the episodes and hosted them and the recordings on a gated page to get leads
• We also used blog posts with insights from various shows to promote it as well
• The main issues we had were with bandwidth (they were a load of work) and Linkedin just being a crappy channel because you couldn’t RSVP to them and you only were notified of the Livestream if you were already online, and sometimes it was glitchy and hard to find

elements.text: I co-hosted a LinkedIn Live stream from March to Mid-July, every week, often multiple times per week. It was pretty successful by most measures but it took a lot of work to get there and it was something our audience was really craving.
We would get about 30-60 people live and then many views (1000s) after the fact.
We paired the live stream with reminder emails, show summaries, and downloads from the experts featured on the show.
We took the recorded streams and chopped them up into bite size snippets for social promotion, that we circulated on social and to our experts/influencers that made them want to share.
We targetted guests who were charasmatic and had big followings, hoping they would drive viewers, which was relatively rare
We would have the same 10-20 people on every stream, and people were genuinely upset when we decided to take a break

Our sales team said that it really helped with prospecting because people had actually already seen the show or heard of it, and if they hadn’t and they suggested it they said it made our brand look really high-quality and cool
We actively encouraged people to chat and ask questions which was great for engagement
We heavily branded and structured the show, which people really responded to
We transcribed all the episodes and hosted them and the recordings on a gated page to get leads
We also used blog posts with insights from various shows to promote it as well

The main issues we had were with bandwidth (they were a load of work) and Linkedin just being a crappy channel because you couldn’t RSVP to them and you only were notified of the Livestream if you were already online, and sometimes it was glitchy and hard to find

text:
Hi all, has anyone ever received a cease and desist from another website about content you've published? We received an email asking us to remove the article or they'll proceed with legal action (not sure what exactly).

In the C&D email they included a link to our post, saying it infringes their copyright, but didn't point out anything in particular from it. Plagiarism checkers flag nothing. The article concept is similar, because it targets the same keyword, but nothing that's actually the same.

Not sure what best course of action is here... Could it just be a templated email that some companies send out to all of their competition to take down competing posts...? Is there actually any potential risk for us? If anyone has been in a similar situation, it'd be great to hear your thoughts.

elements.text:
Hi all, has anyone ever received a cease and desist from another website about content you've published? We received an email asking us to remove the article or they'll proceed with legal action (not sure what exactly).

In the C&D email they included a link to our post, saying it infringes their copyright, but didn't point out anything in particular from it. Plagiarism checkers flag nothing. The article concept is similar, because it targets the same keyword, but nothing that's actually the same.

Not sure what best course of action is here... Could it just be a templated email that some companies send out to all of their competition to take down competing posts...? Is there actually any potential risk for us? If anyone has been in a similar situation, it'd be great to hear your thoughts.

text: I have seen this, I think it’s an odd type of spam email / negative SEO, trying to bait people into deleting competing content (I imagine it works particularly well with less involved businesses that hire freelancers which will just fire the freelancers and delete the post immediately because they don’t know any better and can’t be bothered to look into it)

text:
Yeah Zoom call. I’d just bring together people that have worked in-house & agency (like yourself) as well as those that have only ever done one or the other in a Zoom room for a conversation — basically to give them the opportunity to talk about their positive/negative experiences. 

Useful for agency owners to understand what the mindset of the person they want to hire is. Also useful for people looking to get hired & aren’t sure what they want, etc.

elements.text: Yeah Zoom call. I’d just bring together people that have worked in-house & agency (like yourself) as well as those that have only ever done one or the other in a Zoom room for a conversation — basically to give them the opportunity to talk about their positive/negative experiences.
Useful for agency owners to understand what the mindset of the person they want to hire is. Also useful for people looking to get hired & aren’t sure what they want, etc.

text: If there's nothing that matches in the articles, than it could be a scare technique to make the competition delete the article. You can use Copyscape to <https://www.copyscape.com/compare.php|compare two links> and make sure there are no matches as a proof that will back your claims.

text: <@U017WA1NKT4> yikes, this one is a :triangular_flag_on_post: to me. I had a similar company ask this and then I emailed them back saying it would take them about a full day’s work. I also provided some feedback to them and their hiring team as this would turn a lot of potential candidates away. You should be paid for a trial assignment that is extensive as this.
